reviewText:
Short version: 83%The sequel of 12 Labours of Hercules brings more levels, increased challenge, and additional game mechanics to this enjoyable time management game. Sadly, it still couldn’t afford to have some form of story.

Long version:12 Labours of Hercules II: The Cretan Bull is the second instalment in a fairly successful line of time management games. Just like its predecessor, this one has no actual story or any real connection to the mythical jobs of Heracles, the title is just an excuse for the pleasant visual theme.

The core game mechanics are the same as before: you have a set of servants who are used to gather resources in order to remove road blocks to the next level. There are more instances where you need to call upon the help of Hercules himself or one of his mythological friends, but the bulk of the work still falls on the never-tiring servants.

Since a sequel needs some new gameplay elements, there are also a number of changes. Storage space is unlimited, but farms have to be harvested manually, before thieves steal the resources. You now start with at least two servants and most levels offer some form of achievable bonus to boost their efficiency; but you need to be a lot more careful and faster to clear the increased amount of obstacles to reach the bonus time limits.

The result is a sequel that is a little easier for casual players but a lot harder for those who want to get every award, which is probably the best outcome both sides could hope for.

Just like before, this one is a time management game where, this time, Hercules faces off against the goddess Hera, who has been set up as the villain. Then, they will unlock bonus levels which you can play for additional fun.  The levels are the same as before and there are the mini-games, just like in the previous game. There's relaxed, casual, and expert so you can choose which difficulty suits you best.

Overall, I found this sequel to be more challenging than the first one although just as fun.  I highly recommend it to anyone who's a fan of time management games and would like to spend time playing one.

12 Labours of Hercules: Cretan Bull is the second installment of its' series developed by JetDogs Studios and Zoomout Games. Previous installment: 12 Labours of Hercules.

Note: There is a storyline for the game but it isn't much to it nor its' rememberable. Gameplay formula is pretty much the same as the first one.

This is a time management game, where careful planning is required, limited amount of resources that are available throughout the game; henced the word management.

This game has the total of four episodes with 11 levels each; totaling out 44 levels altogether. There twenty-two different achievements but each of them come with a requirement.  There are also puzzle pieces to find throughout the game. The four bonus levels can be unlock when the jigsaw puzzle is completed.

There are three modes, relaxed; casual and expert, the difference between them is the timer speed and scoring. In relaxed mode, no timer and no scoring. In casual mode, the timer drain a slowly and the scoring is moderately low. In expert mode, the timer drain much quicker and the scoring is much higher.

The stars that are earned from completing the level depends upon on how much time is left on the timer. This only applies to the causal and expert modes

Three Gold star is when the time has not gone pass the arrow. Two Silver star is when the time has gone pass the arrow. One Bronze star is when the timer is completely empty.

Replaying any of the levels will improve the game score and the amount star.

There are few special bonuses: Freeze Time, Worker Movement/Work Speed, Additional Worker and Increases Resources. All of these special bonuses has a certain time limit but they can be used again once the bar fills-up. These special bonuses are very useful when the game is being played on expert mode.

I don't think that this game much of replay value to it. If you're into time management games then you might find this game somewhat enjoyable to certain extent.

reviewText:
For a game I bought for $0.14, I wasn't really expecting anything.  Surprisingly, it's actually a really fun RTS-style game.  It's a lot simpler than other RTS-style games (only uses mouse so you don't have to worry about needing to have a crazy APM in order to beat the game or have fun).  It's relatively simple to understand, and the game is hard to put down once you get past the first few levels.

There's 40+ levels in this game (not entirely sure how many, but definitely 8-10+ hours worth of solid gameplay), and each of them build on the previous in terms of complexity/difficulty.  As of right now I'm a little more than halfway done with the game, and I haven't had any problem whatsoever getting 3/3 stars on every level so far on medium difficulty.  If you're one to play only on the highest difficulties, then you'll definitely get challenged.  Relaxed (the easiest diffuculty)  isn't so boringly easy either, so I think this game is able to appeal to a lot wider audience.

While this game definitely isn't trying to be one of the harder/more complex RTSes out there, I think it's perfectly fine for what it does.  Pick this game up if you have any doubts, it's easily one of the best game for its price.

reviewText:
This time management game continues on from where the last one left off. It focus's on Hercules 7th labor of penance according to the real myth which was to kill a cretan bull that was going around terrorising Crete. In the real myth Hercules stangles it with his bare hands. In game i think he gets it to roll over and gives it a belly rub or something. Must confess I wasn't paying much attention to the story.

The mechanics of this one if fairly much the same as the previous. The only exception being that a puzzle piece is hidden on each map for you to find. Which when you find them all will unlock four more levels.

44 Levels, 4 of which involve some sort of boss fight or minigame. These minigames are easy to get a perfect achievement on in comparison to how infuriating they were in the previous one. However this does not mean that achievement hunters like myself will not come across some aggrevating predicaments.

If you are an achievement hunter then i STRONGLY suggest the following. Place the difficulty on the easiest setting. Complete five maps and find the puzzle piece in that map. Do not log out when you have found the puzzle piece as you MUST complete the map you are on. Once you have the 5 puzzle piece achievement, turn the difficulty of the maps up and start earning three stars on all the maps. Remember you have to get all achievements on one profile. Hopefully that will save you from doing two or three walkthroughs of this game like I had to.

Last thing worth mentioning is the fact that they have added a Developers record time which you must pass at least ten times. This is actually quite challenging and makes a good addition for the game. In a nutshell a fun game to pass some time on if your looking for something that will have you in a click frenzy. With all the running around the servants do while wearing short toga's, all I've got to say is this 'thank God they wore underwear back then'.

12 Labours of Hercules II: The Cretan Bull is a casual time-puzzle game. Hera's Cretan Bull is on a rampage, and it's up to Hercules and his servant to put a stop to its destruction and tame the beast.

Pros: Much like the previous game, Hercules orders his servant around in single-screen puzzles, where you must reach a variety your objectives by picking up resources and accomplishing tasks that consumes those same resources, tasks such as fixing the path or upgrading buildings, all within a set time limit. Every once-in-a-while, you'll need to enroll the help of allies from the previous games, such as as the Medusa, the Pegasus, the Cyclops and the Cerberus, in order to defeat certain obstacles. You must also fend off thieves who will steam your resources if you don't collect them quickly enough, while Hero appear every so often to scare your servants from doing their work.

Cons: The game is basically additional levels from the previous one, with little innovation. There are no new resources, and you barely ever get to use the Lion, the only new ally that joins you in this game. The graphics are exactly the same as the previous one with no apparant advance or additional investment from the artist. The world overlay has much less to do with anciant Greece, and the landmarks you build from getting a Gold Victory in levels are actually modern-looking zoos or resorts. The story is even poorer, and seems more like an excuse to make rimes.

Verdict: ★★★☆☆ - It's up to you

The game feels even more targeted for a younger audience than the previous 12 Labours of Hercules, but I've come to assume that it is on purpose considering the low difficulty and extremely childish tale. If you're looking for challenging puzzles, stay away. But if you're looking a child's game to develop hand-eye coordination of mouse dexterity, this might just be what you're looking for.

reviewText: This game is not so bad. But after 6 hours i got bored. But for 15 cents PERFECT !

At first, this seems like Farmville on a hefty dose of meth. You're clicking like crazy. Starcraft 2 pro-game kind of crazy.

But then you start to figure out the finer points of the game, and the insane clicking evolves into a more measured, meta-approach to each level, with the player weighing options of which path to continue down (by clicking) for the fastest results. Once you've made that transition, the game is a nice balance between keeping up your clicks and carefully planning your approach.

It won't hold your attention forever, but as a palette cleanser and a diversion for when you don't have the chutzpah for a long involved game, this is solid gold.

Price
I got it when it was on sale for 14 cents...because why not?

~Clicker Game*
1. Collect Materials

3. Complete level perfectly
*Definitely the FB/Phone type of game.

Now Hercules is no more sleeping but he's rather waiting until you can send him do some works: moving rocks mainly.
